User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the VApps Success Hub platform.

firstName.description: The first name of the user.

lastName.description: The last name of the user.

email.description: The email address of the user.

role.description: The role of the user (e.g., admin, coach, client).

dateJoined.description: The date and time the user joined the platform.

Appointment.title: Appointment
Appointment.description: Represents a scheduled appointment between a coach and a client.

coachId.description: Reference to User representing the coach. (Relationship: User 1:N Appointment)

clientId.description: Reference to User representing the client. (Relationship: User 1:N Appointment)

startTime.description: The start date and time of the appointment.

endTime.description: The end date and time of the appointment.

status.description: The status of the appointment (e.g., scheduled, completed, cancelled).

id.description: Unique identifier for the email campaign.

name.description: The name of the email campaign.

subject.description: The subject line of the email campaign.

body.description: The HTML or plain text body of the email campaign.

segment.description: User segment targeted by the email campaign (e.g., new sign-ups, inactive users).

scheduledTime.description: The date and time the email campaign is scheduled to be sent.

status.description: The status of the email campaign (e.g., draft, scheduled, sent, completed).

Message.title: Message
Message.description: Represents a message sent between users on the platform.

senderId.description: Reference to User who sent the message. (Relationship: User 1:N Message)

recipientId.description: Reference to User who received the message. (Relationship: User 1:N Message)

timestamp.description: The date and time the message was sent.

isRead.description: Indicates whether the recipient has read the message.

Invoice.title: Invoice
Invoice.description: Represents an invoice for coaching sessions or other services.

clientId.description: Reference to User who is the client for the invoice. (Relationship: User 1:N Invoice)

issueDate.description: The date the invoice was issued.

dueDate.description: The date the invoice is due.

amount.description: The total amount due on the invoice.

status.description: The status of the invoice (e.g., pending, paid, overdue).

Consent.title: Consent
Consent.description: Represents a user's consent to data processing, in line with GDPR.

id.description: Unique identifier for the consent record.

userId.description: Reference to User who provided consent. (Relationship: User 1:N Consent)

consentType.description: The type of consent (e.g., marketing emails, data sharing).

consentGiven.description: Indicates whether the user has given consent.

timestamp.description: The date and time the consent was given or withdrawn.

LandingPage.title: LandingPage
LandingPage.description: Represents the configuration and content of the landing page.

id.description: Unique identifier for the landing page configuration.

title.description: The title of the landing page.

content.description: The content of the landing page, stored as HTML or JSON.

lastUpdated.description: The date and time the landing page was last updated.

status.description: The status of the landing page (e.g., draft, published).

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to align with the application's core features, emphasizing user-centric data organization and secure access patterns. The structure leverages path-based ownership for user-related data (appointments, messages, invoices, consents) and segregates global data (landing pages, email campaigns). Authorization Independence is achieved by avoiding `get()` calls in security rules through path-based ownership and DBAC with no custom claims.

**Explanation of Authorization Independence (Denormalization):**

*   For entities like `Appointment`, `Message`, `Invoice`, and `Consent`, which are related to a user, the structure uses path-based ownership (e.g., `/users/{userId}/appointments/{appointmentId}`). This inherently provides authorization context. No `get()` calls are needed because the `request.auth.uid` directly corresponds to the `userId` in the path.

**QAPs (Rules are not Filters) Support:**

*   **Private Data:** Achieved through path-based ownership. For example, listing appointments is secure because the rule checks that `request.auth.uid == userId` in the path `/users/{userId}/appointments`. This prevents unauthorized listing.
*   **Global Roles (DBAC):** The application does not use explicit global roles since authorization relies solely on `request.auth.uid`.

**Detailed Structure Explanation:**

*   `/users/{userId}`: Stores user profiles. All user-owned data resides under this path.
*   `/users/{userId}/appointments/{appointmentId}`: Appointments are stored as subcollections of users, enforcing ownership.
*   `/users/{userId}/messages/{messageId}`: Messages are stored as subcollections of users, ensuring that users can only access their own messages.
*   `/users/{userId}/invoices/{invoiceId}`: Invoices are stored as subcollections of users, guaranteeing that users can only manage their own invoices.
*   `/users/{userId}/consents/{consentId}`: Consents are stored as subcollections of users, ensuring users control their data.
*   `/landing_pages/{landingPageId}`: Stores landing page configurations.  Administrators would be granted access via security rules, which would be based on their `uid` if they existed in a `/roles_admin/{uid}` document.
*   `/email_campaigns/{emailCampaignId}`: Stores email campaigns, managed by authorized users (e.g., admins) based on a membership map or a dedicated role collection.
